urn:contentItem:6BXW-29K1-JDJN-649N-00000-00This tech investor will pay Ukrainian farmers to trap carbon in their soil2024-05-02T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:43:49ZLexisNexisThis tech investor will pay Ukrainian farmers to trap carbon in their soil

Lithuanian climate investment firm HeavyFinance has added over 700,000 football pitches-worth of farmland in Ukraine to its soil carbon credit programme.

Modern agriculture has taken its toll on soils. Centuries of plowing, cutting, and overgrazing has made land less fertile. This has also released billions of tonnes of CO2 into the atmosphere.

HeavyFinance pays farmers to put some of this carbon back into the ground.

Specifically, the company issues loans to encourage the switch to regenerative farming practices. This includes rotating crops, growing cover crops during the off season, or plowing less often. These processes can remove carbon from the atmosphere and store it in the soil to arrive at a number.

Once farmers have transitioned to this new way of agriculture, HeavyFinance measures how much carbon they have stored. The company does this using satellite data and soil samples. It measures carbon levels in the soil before and after the changes.

In the case of Ukraine, local company Agsolco, will verify and issue the soil carbon credits. Companies or countries will buy these tokens as a way to offset their emissions.

The more carbon farmers pull from the atmosphere, the more money they can make. In war-torn Ukraine, this could provide a valuable income stream.

"Switching to regenerative agriculture gives farmers the opportunity to improve their soil and store more carbon at the same time," said Laimonas Noreika, CEO and co-founder of HeavyFinance.

A growing market for soil carbon credits

In March, HeavyFinance secured €50mn in debt financing, with €20mn coming from the European Investment Fund (EIF). It has already added 250,000 hectares of land to its carbon farming programme, including countries such as Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, and Portugal.

The Lithuanian company is far from the only one betting big on soil carbon credits. Agreena, a soil carbon credit provider from Denmark, now has two million hectares of farmland under its management. Across the Atlantic, US-based Indigo has secured hundreds of millions of dollars for its own soil carbon marketplace.

Proponents say soil carbon credits offer a way to draw down CO2 and improve cash flow for struggling farmers. But some critics question the science behind it.

Issuing soil carbon credits relies on broad estimates of how much carbon has been stored. While technologies like satellites and drones are improving coverage, it's still unfeasible to take measurements of every single field or patch of soil. What's more, researchers still don't fully understand the science of how soils store and release carbon.

Nevertheless, buyers of soil carbon credits see them as a safer bet compared to forest offset credits, issued in exchange for protecting forests at risk of destruction. Issuers have come under mounting scrutiny for overinflating the value of these credits, causing many companies to stop purchasing them.

HeavyFinance estimates that applying regenerative practices across Ukraine's entire agricultural estate can reduce 757.7 million tonnes of CO2 emissions. This is equivalent to the total annual carbon output of Germany.

urn:contentItem:6944-9401-JDJN-64D3-00000-00Berlin tech companies join forces to plant trees when you travel by train2023-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:43:48ZLexisNexisBerlin tech companies join forces to plant trees when you travel by train

German multi-modal travel unicorn Omio has teamed up with compatriot search engine Ecosia to create a tree-planting rail travel booking tool. It means users will be able to search and book train journeys through Ecosia's website, powered by an API-integration with Omio's travel platform.

The booking platform will automatically pop up via a simple query search for trains, or for destinations where train travel is possible, say London to Paris. It will be available in 15 countries: the UK, Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Nordics, North America and Canada, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, and Ukraine.

The intention behind the new tool being rolled out this month is two-fold. Firstly, to make sustainable rail options more visible as an alternative to air travel. Secondly, all the commission Ecosia receives from successful bookings will go directly toward the search engine's green initiatives.

Note that this is not a form of offsetting, meaning that it is not intended to "cancel out" any carbon emissions produced by your journey (a popular but, let's face it, greenwashing tool employed by airlines during the booking process).

Catch up on our conference talks

Watch videos of our past talks for free with TNW All Access →

Providers accessible through the new tool include Amtrak in the United States, LNER, GWR, Avanti in the UK, SNCF in France, OBB in Austria and Eurostar.

Born from the Berlin startup scene

In the land of internet searches, where one company is so synonymous with the activity that it has become a verb, you'd be forgiven for not having heard of Ecosia. However, the platform does see 20 million users globally every month.

Founded in 2009 by Christian Kroll, the tech company dedicates 100% of its profits to planet-friendly initiatives. These include having planted over 175 million trees all over the world, in collaboration with local communities.

The company, the first to become an accredited B Corp in Germany in 2014, has also supported regenerative agriculture projects, and invested into renewable energy.

"Our users want choice over how they travel, and they want to travel sustainably — that's evident in the sheer volume of searches we're seeing each month on Ecosia," said the company's Chief Product Officer Michael Metcalf.

"If a healthy proportion of the two million searches made for train journeys on Ecosia each month translate into bookings, this will allow us to invest in our other environmental initiatives pushing back against the climate emergency," he continued.

Fellow Berliner Omio was first introduced as GoEuro in 2013 by founder Naren Shaam. Today, the multi-modal platform issues travel tickets across 37 countries, in 21 different languages, and 26 different currencies, for 1000+ travel transportation providers.

Following a growth of 100% up until 2019, Omio experienced a couple of incredibly tough years during the pandemic where 98% of the company's revenue basically evaporated overnight. However, almost exactly a year ago, Omio announced a Series E funding of $80mn (approx. €72mn) to take its total funding up to $480mn (€434mn).

urn:contentItem:616H-SKM1-JB14-701R-00000-00Regenerative farming with innovative Eggmobile concept2020-11-20T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:43:49ZLexisNexisARTICLERegenerative farming with innovative Eggmobile conceptNatalie Berkhout

Farmer Angus McIntosh’s ‘green transition’ happened when he left his corporate career as an accomplished stockbroker in London, to return home to South Africa to build a clay home and become a barefoot regenerative farmer. On his farm, the chickens are housed in Eggmobiles and are moved daily to live off the land.

Regenerative agriculture

“The cornerstone of regenerative agriculture is the rotation of animals across the land,” says McIntosh, adding: “Regenerative agriculture has three main goals which are: to produce nutrient-dense food, to heal the Earth and to create employment.” This is facilitated on the farm by rotationally grazing the pigs and cattle, as well as the chickens that are housed in Eggmobiles. About 18 varieties of perennial plants, grasses and legumes are also planted on the land.

Eggmobiles as chicken houses

Eggmobiles are mobile chicken houses that are moved to new pasture every day. Inside the unit, the nest boxes are painted black and are filled with sawdust and two handfuls of diatomaceous earth which keeps the skin free of parasites. The floor of each unit is mesh, while solar panels control the lighting which is used to extend normal daylight in the winter months, keeping the total light at 15 hours and 30 minutes. No heating is provided.

Truly free-range chickens

The hens are let out during the day to forage and peck, and then return at night to where they are warm and safe from predators. Eggs are collected three times a day from the nest boxes in the middle of the Eggmobiles. Angus McIntosh currently has 22 Eggmobiles each housing 325 Amberlink and Leghorn birds. The chickens arrive at the farm at 19 weeks of age and are kept for 64 weeks. He and his team – one worker can handle four Eggmobiles (1,300 birds) – collect about 5,100 eggs a day. Flocks are vaccinated for Newcastle disease and infectious bronchitis, but the birds are never given routine antibiotics or hormones.

The most nutritious eggs

According to the farm’s director, Thobelani Mngomezulu, the Eggmobiles are moved every day to fertilise the pasture and to avoid over-fertilising the soil. “We get our chickens to graze on our pasture to ensure they lay the most nutritious eggs,” he said, adding that the enormous amount of manure and urine that is deposited onto the soil eliminates the need to apply any artificial fertilisers. The chickens are fed 85% non-GMO, glyphosate-free laying mash which is specifically formulated for the farm. Each hen consumes an average of about 140g per day.

“The great advantages of this business are that the hens are healthy and happy, and they produce the most nutrient-­dense eggs,” says Farmer Angus who, together with his team, are developing a big turnkey egg production facility in conjunction with South Africa’s Department of Agriculture with the aim of growing the farm’s Eggmobile concept.

Farmer Angus, the brand

With increasing demand from consumers for sustainable farming practices, as well as calls for improved animal welfare throughout the production process, the Farmer Angus philosophy and brand has a loyal following, and it is growing. McIntosh notes: “Most clients don’t want to support the caged system which produces 96% of all eggs in South Africa. We produce the most nutritious eggs in the land and our customers love them.”

A third of the farm’s egg production is supplied to the hospitality industry and the remainder is distributed through a network of nationwide retailers. Although they are not the most expensive eggs in the retail environment, Farmer Angus is indeed a premium brand and South Africans can expect to pay three times the price of non-free-range eggs. In addition to eggs, and for the convenience of bakery and ice-cream clients, Farmer Angus also sells egg white or egg yolks in 1 litre or 5 litre boxes, and for local clients, egg whites are also sold in 500ml bags.

Inside the Eggmobiles the nest boxes are painted black and are filled with sawdust. The floor is made of mesh, while solar panels control the lighting. There are no heating units.

Farmer Angus’ farm, Spier, is set amid the Hottentots Holland mountain range in the Western Cape peninsula of South Africa.

urn:contentItem:66PH-01F1-DXG5-Y2K9-00000-00The future of sustainability through nutrition2022-10-28T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:43:48ZLexisNexisARTICLEThe future of sustainability through nutritionCasey Bradley

In today’s political landscape, many are using the buzzwords: Global Warming, Carbon Credits, and Sustainability. However, many times true sustainability is not considered, especially when animal agriculture is brought into the discussion.

With carbon neutrality being the ultimate objective, many industries are considering renewable energy sources like wind, solar, and hydroelectricity. Additionally, biofuels and electric vehicles are front runners in sustainability discussions while, more recently, discussion around alternative foods have begun to emerge. Over the last few decades, animal agriculture has utilised genetics, improved housing, management changes, and nutritional strategies to become more efficient protein producers. These improvements have resulted in tremendous improvements in sustainability, from land and water usage to emissions. Although agriculture continues to make strides towards better sustainability, current social and political landscapes will present some of the biggest challenges today’s production has seen and will test the true sustainability of animal agriculture.

Over the last few decades, animal agriculture has utilised genetics, improved housing and management changes, and nutritional strategies to become more efficient protein producers, which has also resulted in tremendous improvements in sustainability, from land and water usage to emissions. However, these current social and political landscapes will challenge today’s production systems further, in which the true sustainability of animal agriculture will be tested.

Low protein diets and feed additives

One area of exploration to reduce ammonia and other greenhouse gases in monogastric systems is with low crude protein diets with substitution of crystalline amino acids (CAA) and other feed additives. This area is not a new concept as a study reported that feeding reduced crude protein (CP) diets (12.2% versus 18.7% CP) produced a 40% reduction in aerial ammonia concentrations. Further studies have shown that decreasing dietary protein in finishing pigs from 22 to 18 to 16 to 13% results in reduced ammonia emission rates per animal of 8.27, 5.89, 3.89 and 3.11, g d−1 animal−1, respectively (P<0.001). Hence any reduction in dietary protein will be of benefit in terms of reducing nitrogen emissions.

Phytase

Phytase has been a feed additive utilised in swine and poultry diets for over three decades now, primarily for its ability to utilise bound phosphorus in feedstuffs. Continued research has demonstrated that it also can improve protein and amino acid digestibility. The University of Arkansas was one of the first groups to demonstrate that supplementing swine diets with phytase had the ability to reduce ammonia emissions by 26% and ultimately N runoff loss. This work was part of the AR Water Grant that also investigated long term runoff and soil nutrient retention. Through their work they demonstrated that both total and soluble P was reduced in the manure and in runoff. Additionally, when the same plots were utilised for grazing by cattle they demonstrated over a two-year period a 17% improvement in gain per acre, and a 18% increase in P and N removal through grazing (Figure 1). This trial demonstrated a true sustainable approach to livestock production before regenerative agriculture became a new buzzword. Ultimately, phytase research has continued to provide strategies to producers for continued growth performance and efficiency, while also utilising less digestible feedstuffs in neonatal diets.

Proteases

Proteases are another enzyme that is predominately utilised in poultry versus swine rations. Using proteases enhances the protein and amino acid digestibility of lower-quality protein sources, providing a sustainable strategy for poultry and swine operations. Low crude protein diets have also been researched extensively for swine and poultry rations, with advantageous results. From an LCA perspective, protease can reduce N content in the manure and emissions in poultry systems in both low and normal protein-level diets but is more effective when utilised in low protein diets (Figure 2). Their research also indicated a reduction in eutrophication, acidification, and global warming equivalents with the use of proteases in broiler rations, especially when utilised with low protein diets.

Unlocking the secrets of the deep blue sea

As animal nutritionists look for alternative feedstuffs and approaches to mitigating emissions from livestock operations, seaweed has become an intriguing feedstuff, especially for ruminants. In the mainstream media methane burping cows are being targeted for climate change initiatives. One key opportunity for ruminant nutritionists is the use of different seaweed extracts or products, which can reduce methane production by up to 90% in herds. The benefits of seaweed go beyond methane reductions, but also improvements in feed efficiency and herd health. Additionally, kelp is relatively high in microminerals while being more bioavailable, reducing the need for mining of these traditional trace minerals. The prebiotic effects of different algae are also being utilised as strategies to replace growth promoting antibiotics and trace minerals, such as zinc and copper in swine diets.

The value of utilising the sea as a feedstuff is also even more intriguing from a land management perspective and offers limitless opportunities to harvest the sea’s grasses for livestock. Companies like Ocean Harvest Technology is taking sustainability one step further by combining the removal of plastics from the ocean with sustainable harvesting methods while providing an income source to once fishermen in Southeast Asia. The known benefits of the ocean’s grasses are just beginning to be unlocked but will play a role in the future of sustainable land-bound livestock production.

Collaboration is the way forward

Today’s feed additive research has heavily relied on researching one specific product at a specific time point of an animal’s life. To truly move the needle on efficiencies and sustainability, nutritional research will need to evolve to better understand biological interactions and synergies while finding the best approaches to applying technologies. This is just starting in today’s nutritional programmes as we add formulation models to include nutrient inputs and outputs of our systems. Furthermore, collaboration across animal health, nutrition, agronomy, and food production is paramount to fully capture and re-utilise key nutrients versus creating uncaptured emissions.

urn:contentItem:6CVD-D301-JB14-700R-00000-00Peulvruchten, no-brainer voor duurzaam en gezond2024-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:43:48ZLexisNexisOPIPeulvruchten, no-brainer voor duurzaam en gezondJolijn Zwart - van Kessel

De teelt en consumptie van peulvruchten bieden duidelijke voordelen en zijn daarom wat Jolijn Zwart–van Kessel betreft een no-brainer in een regene-ratief landbouwsysteem.

Het advies van de Gezondheidsraad aan Nederlanders om meer plantaardig voedsel te eten is niet alleen gebaseerd op gezondheidsvoordelen, maar ook op duurzaamheidsoverwegingen. Peulvruchten zoals bonen, kikkererwten, linzen, en lupine zijn uitstekende bronnen van plantaardige eiwitten en dragen bij aan een gezonder dieet.

In Nederland is de teelt van peulvruchten echter sterk verminderd, ondanks dat ze historisch gezien een belangrijk gewas waren. De afname in teelt is deels te wijten aan onder andere de stijgende import van peulvruchten uit landen met lagere productiekosten en consumptiepatronen die verschuiven naar andere eiwitbronnen zoals vlees, zuivel en soja als vleesvervangers.

Gelukkig zijn er positieve ontwikkelingen zichtbaar. De producentenorganisatie Eiwitboeren van Nederland, opgericht om de belangen van Nederlandse eiwitproducenten te behartigen, heeft al meer dan 150 telers aan zich weten te binden. Door ketenafspraken te verbeteren, zoals ook in de Bean Deal wordt gepropageerd, worden boeren gefaciliteerd om peulvruchten rendabeler te verbouwen. Dit is een cruciale stap richting een duurzamere landbouwpraktijk en een betere voedselzekerheid.

Stikstof binden

Peulvruchten hebben het vermogen om stikstof uit de lucht te binden en zorgen voor een goede doorworteling, wat de bodemkwaliteit aanzienlijk verbetert. Dit leidt tot een vermindering van het gebruik van kunstmest, met zowel ecologische als economische voordelen. Daarnaast leveren peulvruchten organisch materiaal via hun stengels, die kunnen worden ondergewerkt in de bodem.

Peulvruchten passen perfect in de eiwitstrategieën van Nederland en Europa, die gericht zijn op een grotere zelfvoorzienendheid in plantaardige eiwitten. De integratie van vlinderbloemige peulvruchten in het bouwplan van boeren is daarom goed voor het milieu, de gezondheid en de economie. Het ondersteunt de overgang naar een regeneratief landbouwsys-teem, dat essentieel is in de strijd tegen klimaatverandering en voor het behoud van duurzame landbouwpraktijken.

Initiatieven zoals het Regenerative Innovation Portfolio en de Regenerative Agriculture Community, opgezet door Foodvalley en EIT-Food, onder de WEF Food Innovation Hub Europe, spelen zowel op Europees niveau als in Nederland met het Re-Ge-NL groeifonds initiatief een leidende rol. Deze initiatieven bevorderen regeneratieve landbouwpraktijken en bieden een platform voor betrokkenheid en samenwerking van boer tot bord.

Investeren in peulvruchten

Kortom, de teelt en consumptie van peulvruchten bieden duidelijke voordelen en zijn daarom wat mij betreft een no-brainer in een regeneratief landbouwsysteem. Door te investeren in deze gewassen en de keten rondom peulvruchten te versterken, kunnen we onze voedselproductie duurzamer maken en tegelijkertijd zorgen voor een gezonder dieet voor iedereen.

urn:contentItem:6CY6-11T1-DXG5-Y00B-00000-00Regeneratieve landbouw, nieuw toverwoord2024-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T22:43:48ZLexisNexisBUSINESSRegeneratieve landbouw, nieuw toverwoordRochus Kingmans

Regeneratieve landbouw; na kringlooplandbouw en natuurinclusieve landbouw is dit het nieuwe toverwoord in de wereldwijde zoektocht naar een duurzamer landbouwsysteem. Het is geen hype, mede als gevolg van internationale afspraken steken bijna alle grote ketenpartijen over de hele wereld tijd, energie en geld in het concreet maken van dit containerbegrip.

egeneratieve landbouw is een vorm van duurzame landbouw met een positieve bijdrage aan een levende bodem en het milieu. Het streeft naar minimale bodemverstoring, maximalisatie van (bio)diversiteit en het gebruik van natuurlijke processen.” Dat zegt Mark Manshanden, economisch onderzoeker akkerbouw bij WUR. Hij was en is betrokken bij de eerste en tweede PPS (publiek-private samenwerking) over regeneratieve landbouw. Daarbij zijn naast WUR onder meer ook FrieslandCampina, Rabobank en Cosun betrokken. Om de definitie voor akkerbouwers concreter te maken, noemt hij een aantal regeneratieve praktijken: “Een brede gewasrotatie, sterke reductie in chemische input, geen of minder grondbewerking, groenbemesters, implementatie van agroforestry, waterbeheer, vergroten van (bio)diversiteit en biologische plaagbestrijding.”

Guus van Laarhoven, strateeg regeneratieve landbouw bij FrieslandCampina, noemt het ‘een integraal, holistisch landbouwsysteem met meetbare uitkomsten gebaseerd op natuurlijke processen’. “We zien het als een van de oplossingsrichtingen, kansrijke routes voor de uitdagingen waar we als gehele voedselketen voor staan. Afnemers van onze zuivel zien ook kansen en zijn bereid om hierin te investeren.” Een uitdaging waarin boeren een centrale rol spelen, in die zin biedt regeneratieve landbouw hen kansen. Guus’ collega Sanne Griffioen-Roose, directeur duurzame melkveehouderij: “Er is bij onze leden veel nieuwsgierigheid en interesse om de toekomst in eigen hand te nemen. Om een positieve bijdrage te leveren aan vermindering van ammoniak- en methaanemissie, aan meer biodiversiteit.”

ReGeNL: miljoenenproject

Toch klinkt het nog steeds vaag en wollig, maar daar komt verandering in als het aan Wouter Jan Schouten ligt. De voormalige consultant bij de Boston Consulting Group is animator en programmadirecteur van ReGeNL dat deze maand start. Een ambitieus innovatieprogramma met een looptijd van zeven jaar en gefinancierd met € 129miljoen vanuit het Nationaal Groeifonds. Waarbij private partijen gezamenlijk nog eens € 100miljoen moeten inleggen. “Als beloning voor de inspanningen en risico’s van de uiteindelijk duizend boeren die onderdeel worden van het programma”, aldus Schouten.

ReGeNL richt zich op vijf actielijnen. Als eerste bedrijfsmodellen, waarbij het begint met acht bedrijfsmodellen. Die worden naast veertien regeneratieve thema’s gelegd zoals bodemkwaliteit en -vruchtbaarheid, genetische diversiteit en boerenin-komen. Uit al deze combinaties zal een ‘menukaart’ worden ontwikkeld, een beperkte set van bedrijfsmodellen met concrete maatregelen die het begrip regeneratief concreet en behapbaar maken.

Verder worden bestaande en nieuwe innovaties beproefd bij de duizend deelnemende boeren, en worden veel data verzameld voor het meten, voorspellen en waarderen van regeneratieve praktijken. De vierde actielijn richt zich op onderwijsvernieuwingen en leernetwerken voor regeneratieve landbouw. Als laatste wil ReGeNL ondersteunende producten en diensten voor regeneratieve landbouw ontwikkelen. Schouten: “In 2030 willen we voor de meerderheid van de Nederlandse boeren concreet handelingsperspectief kunnen bieden: dit zou voor jou, in jouw context de juiste regeneratieve richting kunnen zijn met een behapbare businesscase en een toekomstbestendig verdienmodel.”

Biologische landbouw

Dat alles duurt dus nog even en je zou kunnen denken waarom niet gewoon overstappen op biologische landbouw? Dat is gecertificeerd, waardoor je precies weet waar je aan moet voldoen en er is een markt. “Biologisch is heel relevant, maar in de praktijk nog steeds een beperkt segment qua omvang”, aldus Schouten. “Uiteindelijk willen we de hele landbouw laten voldoen aan regeneratieve principes.”

Griffioen-Roose: “In de biologische landbouw stuur je aan de voorkant via certificering en hoop je op impact aan de achterkant. Bij regeneratieve landbouw werkt dat andersom. Wat is de impact van toepassing van regeneratieve principes en hoe meet je die? Dat is voor ons als FrieslandCampina heel belangrijk, reden waarom wij alvast beginnen met een proefproject met twintig leden-melkveehouders uit Nederland, België en Duitsland.”

De Deens-Zweedse zuivelcoöperatie Arla Foods begon in 2022 al een vergelijkbare regeneratief project met 24 boeren verdeeld over Zweden, Denemarken, Duitsland, Nederland (twee melkveehouders) en het Verenigd Koninkrijk. Volgens Arla Foods zijn er maar weinig wetenschappelijke voorbeelden van de impact van regeneratieve landbouw. Dus gaat de coöperatie zelf op zoek, waarbij de proefbedrijven worden doorgemeten op vier thema’s: bodemonderzoek, ecosysteem­processen, habitat & biodiversiteit en sociale verandering.

Niet alleen de Europese zuivel stort zich op regeneratieve landbouw. CEO Jacob-Aarup Andersen van bierbrouwer Carlsberg benadrukte onlangs dat steeds meer leveranciers van gerst en hop overschakelen op regeneratieve landbouwmethoden. “Als de Deense boeren deze trend niet volgen, zullen we genoodzaakt zijn onze grondstoffen elders in te kopen.” Carlsberg wil uiteindelijk dat in 2040 al zijn grondstoffen afkomstig zijn uit regeneratieve landbouw.

Geen hype

Cynici zouden kunnen zeggen dat Europese en wereldwijd opererende bedrijven nu pas in beweging komen omdat ze daartoe verplicht worden vanuit CSRD (Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive), de EU-richtlijn die om te beginnen vanaf dit jaar grote bedrijven verplicht een duurzaamheidsrapportage uit te brengen. Of het Parijsakkoord, waarin wereldwijd afspraken zijn gemaakt om de uitstoot van broeikasgassen te verminderen.

Gert Sikken, directeur agro development bij Cosun, vindt dat te kort door de bocht. Hij ziet dat bedrijven al langer bezig zijn met het verduurzamen van hun business. Dat geldt ook voor Cosun zelf, dat met het programma ‘Groeikracht Cosun’ telers helpt te werken aan een toekomstbestendige teelt. “Regeneratieve landbouwprincipes kunnen ons daarbij helpen, daarom participeren we in ReGeNL”, aldus Sikken.

Pierre Berntsen, directeur agrarische bedrijven bij ABN Amro, ziet wel dat CSRD en het Parijsakkoord van grote invloed zijn op de groei van en aandacht voor regeneratieve landbouw. “Ik verwacht dat de marktvraag verduurzaming straks meer gaat versnellen dan wet- en regel-geving.” Samen met WIJ.land werkt de bank sinds begin 2023 met acht boeren in een proefproject aan regeneratieve landbouw.

Antoine Heideveld, directeur van Het Groene Brein en betrokken bij de eerste PPS over regeneratieve landbouw, is heel positief over de mogelijkheden van regeneratieve landbouw, maar heeft wel een kanttekening bij de rol van de markt. Zijn organisatie werkt met ruim 180 wetenschappers en onderzoekers richting een duurzame samenleving. “Als je kijkt wat de markt wil betalen, bijvoorbeeld voor ecosysteemdiensten, en wat de boer nodig heeft, dan zit daar nog een gat tussen. De overheid zou tijdelijk moeten bijspringen, omdat regeneratieve landbouw heel mooi is om boeren perspectief te bieden.”

De bodem is dé basis onder regeneratieve landbouw. In Nederland start ReGeNL om via proefprojecten met 1.000 boeren het begrip handen en voeten te geven. Wereldwijd omarmen multinationals ‘regen ag’ (regenerative agriculture) als middel om hun duurzaamheidsambities te realiseren. Foto: Mark Pasveer

Mark Pasveer

Het toepassen van strokenteelt in de akkerbouw is een mooi voorbeeld hoe regeneratieve landbouw de bodem bijna letterlijk nieuw leven in wil blazen. Verschillende gewassen naast elkaar verbeteren de biodiversiteit boven de grond en stimuleren het bodemleven. Foto: Peter Roek

Peter Roek

Update of internal rules regarding missions and interinstitutional meetings PE775.721 v01-00 8/24 PV\1325526EN.docx EN  Summary of the "Implementing Provisions Governing Missions Outside the Three Places of Work of the European Parliament" (March 2025) (Annex XII) This decision by the CoP lays out the rules for official missions undertaken by European Parliament committees and delegations outside the Parliament’s three places of work. It covers planning, quotas, composition, authorisation, participation, security, and reporting of such missions. It sets a structured, transparent framework for missions, while reinforcing security, cost control, and political representation, applying the d’Hondt system. It affirms that APAs play no direct role in external missions, marking a boundary between parliamentary support staff and official delegations. 1) Main elements  Missions can include fact-finding visits, interparliamentary delegation meetings, election observation, and participation in international conferences.  Committees and delegations are authorised to undertake a limited number of missions based on six-month programming and defined quotas.  Missions must be politically balanced and reflect gender and geographical diversity. Specific limitations apply during election periods. 2) Membership and participation  Only full or substitute Members of the relevant parliamentary bodies may participate as official members of a mission.  Accompanying Members are allowed in limited cases (e.g. national MEPs or related rapporteurs), with strict conditions and prior approval.  Article 6(2) foresees that "In the case of late cancellations for which no replacement can be found, the political group's place on the mission should be deemed to have been occupied for the purposes of calculating future allocation of seats for missions."  Summary of the "Code of Conduct for Negotiating in the Context of the Ordinary Legislative Procedure" (March 2025) (Annex XIII) This document sets out detailed rules and principles for how Parliament conducts trilogues under the ordinary legislative procedure. It replaces the previous version adopted in 2017, strengthening internal coordination and external visibility of Parliament’s legislative negotiations. The Code of Conduct offers practical guidance to ensure that trilogue negotiations are transparent, accountable, and efficient, reinforcing Parliament’s role as co-legislator. It applies to all stages of the ordinary legislative procedure, including third reading and specific committee formats (joint or temporary committees). 1) Key principles  Parliament should use all procedural options available under the Treaties to enhance its influence.  Negotiating teams must act in a unified and coherent way, preserving the integrity of Parliament’s mandate.  All political groups are entitled to representation in the process. PV\1325526EN.docx 9/24 PE775.721 v01-00 EN 2) Composition and conduct of negotiations  Parliament is represented by a negotiating team composed of the Chair, rapporteur, shadow rapporteurs, and other designated Members.  Only Members may express political positions in trilogues. The team should maintain a single, coherent voice.  Provisional agreements must be approved by the responsible committee before final adoption. 3) APAs supporting role in the trilogue process  A Member of the negotiating team may choose to be personally assisted by an APA in addition to their political group advisor.  When selected, the APA can attend trilogues, interinstitutional technical meetings (ITMs), and related preparatory meetings.  APAs must respect the rules of the Code of Conduct and defend Parliament’s official negotiating position.  APA’s role is to provide logistical, strategic, or content-related assistance as determined by the Member they support, but they do not speak or take political positions during negotiations. 4) Transparency and finalisation  All negotiation steps are reported back to committees.  Agreements are made public and subject to legal-linguistic review.  Parliament commits to informing the public transparently throughout the legislative process. 7.8. Guidance on the Application of Rule 170 RoP - Urgent Procedure The purpose of attached note (Annex XIV) by CCLA/the Directorate for the Plenary and DLA is to inform the Chairs and Coordinators about the constraints associated with the use of the urgent procedure. The urgent procedure under Rule 170 of the EP Rules of Procedure (RoP) is designed for addressing “unforeseen developments” requiring swift legislative action. Excessive reliance on the urgent procedure risks undermining Parliament’s prerogatives as co- legislator and reducing the quality of the legislative output, due to the compressed timeline, the suppression of some steps in the standard procedure or the alteration of working practices (for instance work in English only). Its use should therefore remain exceptional and limited to cases of clear urgency, duly justified by the requestor and where no other option is available to Parliament. Committees are advised to first consider speeding up their normal internal deliberations, for example by applying the simplified procedure under Rule 52, which offers several advantages over the urgent procedure. The simplified procedure accelerates legislative work while ensuring that all key steps of the committee procedure - committee scrutiny, prerogatives of opinion-giving committees and political consultations - are respected, allowing Parliament to respond swiftly to priority files.
